conversation.content: [overly polite] Oh, you're Frank Delacroix from the broadcasts, aren't you? My husband watches you religiously every Sunday, says you're the only one who really understands the game.
[friendly] That's very kind of him to say, and you must be Victoria Ashford. I've seen you at several league events, though we've never been formally introduced until tonight.
[curious] It's interesting that you'd remember me from those events, considering how many people must blur together in your line of work. Do you always have such a good memory for faces?
[slowly] Well, certain people tend to stand out, especially when they're connected to prominent team owners. Your husband's involvement with the league has been quite newsworthy lately.
[very quietly] Newsworthy is such an interesting choice of words. [pause] I suppose everything my husband does becomes public property in your world, doesn't it?

Public property is a bit strong, but when someone owns a team, their business dealings do become matters of public interest. [clears throat] Speaking of which, I've been meaning to ask someone close to the situation about those offshore accounts.
[confused] Offshore accounts?
The ones linked to the betting syndicates in Malta and Cyprus. [pause] Surely you must have noticed the late-night phone calls, the sudden trips to Vegas that don't align with any games?
[bitter] You know, for someone who's supposed to be analyzing plays and statistics, you seem awfully interested in analyzing my marriage.
I'm not analyzing your marriage, Mrs. Ashford. I'm investigating a story that could fundamentally alter how people view the integrity of the sport we all claim to love.
[monotone] And what exactly do you expect me to say to that? That I'll help you destroy everything my husband built because you have some noble journalistic mission?
[empathetically] I don't expect you to say anything, actually. But I thought you deserved to know that this story is coming out, with or without your cooperation, probably within the next two weeks.
[shaky voice] Two weeks. [laughs] That's barely enough time to transfer assets or arrange separate legal representation, not that I'm thinking about such things, of course.
Of course not. Though if someone were thinking about such things, they might also want to know that the FBI has already frozen several accounts as of this morning.
[very quietly] You're not really here for the charity gala, are you? This whole conversation, meeting me here where he can't interfere, it's all calculated.
[sincerely] The gala invitation was legitimate, but yes, I hoped we might talk. You're not just a trophy on his arm, Victoria, despite what everyone assumes.
[coldly] Everyone assumes correctly. I knew exactly what I was signing up for five years ago, and I've played my part perfectly. [pause] The question is whether you're offering me a different role.
Protected source status, full immunity, and a chance to control your own narrative for once. [quietly] My producer has the paperwork in her car if you're interested.
[hesitantly] Your producer just happens to have FBI cooperation agreements in her car at a charity gala. [sighs] I suppose I should ask what happens if I simply walk away right now.
[warmly] Then you walk away, and in two weeks you'll watch your life implode on national television while I provide color commentary. But somehow, I don't think that's what you're going to do.

scenario: A trophy wife encounters her husband's favorite sports commentator at a charity gala, where the commentator reveals they're investigating her husband's illegal gambling connections.
